      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1368230#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Oct 4, 2022, 11:29 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        After reading <span class="line"><!---->After reading <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> afaict this is whats happening (from my understanding of SameSite and redirector chains when flag is enabled)<span class="line"><!----> afaict this is whats happening (from my understanding of SameSite and redirector chains when flag is enabled)<!----></span><br><br>1. Secure samesite cookie behaviour + normal redirect (w/ flag enabled)<span class="line"><!---->1. Secure samesite cookie behaviour + normal redirect (w/ flag enabled)<!----></span><br><br>None (entered in omnibox) -> <span class="line"><!---->None (entered in omnibox) -&gt; <!----></span>http://attacker.site<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://attacker.site"><!---->http://attacker.site<!----></a> (redirector origin) -> <span class="line"><!----> (redirector origin) -&gt; <!----></span>http://httpbin.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://httpbin.org"><!---->http://httpbin.org<!----></a> (SameSite cookie not sent w/ flag enabled as origin 2 =/= origin 3)<span class="line"><!----> (SameSite cookie not sent w/ flag enabled as origin 2 =/= origin 3)<!----></span><br><br>2. Secure samesite cookie behaviour + intent redirect (w/ flag enabled)<span class="line"><!---->2. Secure samesite cookie behaviour + intent redirect (w/ flag enabled)<!----></span><br><br>None (entered in omnibox) -> ??? (redirector origin) -> <span class="line"><!---->None (entered in omnibox) -&gt; ??? (redirector origin) -&gt; <!----></span>http://httpbin.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://httpbin.org"><!---->http://httpbin.org<!----></a> (SameSite cookie sent???)<span class="line"><!----> (SameSite cookie sent???)<!----></span><br><br>So the problem lies whether the origin that redirects to intent fills in the ??? and what value it fills in the redirect chain? (correct me if I am wrong)<span class="line"><!---->So the problem lies whether the origin that redirects to intent fills in the ??? and what value it fills in the redirect chain? (correct me if I am wrong)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Hi mthiesse@, I have done some additional test and am fairly confident that the root cause is that the a redirection to an intent is not populating the origin correctly<span class="line"><!---->Hi mthiesse@, I have done some additional test and am fairly confident that the root cause is that the a redirection to an intent is not populating the origin correctly<!----></span><br><br>If you were to go from Site A -> Site B (redirector) -> Site A normally this is what happens:<span class="line"><!---->If you were to go from Site A -&gt; Site B (redirector) -&gt; Site A normally this is what happens:<!----></span><br><br>http://sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sitea.com"><!---->http://sitea.com<!----></a> -> <span class="line"><!----> -&gt; <!----></span>http://siteb.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://siteb.com"><!---->http://siteb.com<!----></a> (normal redirection) --> <span class="line"><!----> (normal redirection) --&gt; <!----></span>http://sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sitea.com"><!---->http://sitea.com<!----></a><br><br>This request has Sec-Fetch-Site of cross-site because the<span class="line"><!---->This request has Sec-Fetch-Site of cross-site because the<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>siteb.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://siteb.com"><!---->siteb.com<!----></a> =/=<span class="line"><!----> =/=<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sitea.com"><!---->sitea.com<!----></a><br><br>However if you were to redirected to an intent, lets say<span class="line"><!---->However if you were to redirected to an intent, lets say<!----></span><br><br>http://sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sitea.com"><!---->http://sitea.com<!----></a> -> <span class="line"><!----> -&gt; <!----></span>http://siteb.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://siteb.com"><!---->http://siteb.com<!----></a> (intent redirection) --> <span class="line"><!----> (intent redirection) --&gt; <!----></span>http://sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sitea.com"><!---->http://sitea.com<!----></a><br><br>Then this request erroneously has Sec-Fetch-Site of same-origin even when<span class="line"><!---->Then this request erroneously has Sec-Fetch-Site of same-origin even when<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>siteb.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://siteb.com"><!---->siteb.com<!----></a> =/=<span class="line"><!----> =/=<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sitea.com"><!---->sitea.com<!----></a>. <span class="line"><!---->. <!----></span><br><br>My guess is that the whenever redirected to an intent it doesn't populate the origin. So origin remains null. Could you verify this @mthiesse?<span class="line"><!---->My guess is that the whenever redirected to an intent it doesn't populate the origin. So origin remains null. Could you verify this @mthiesse?<!----></span><br><br>This is a Sec-Fetch-Site bypass too (see <span class="line"><!---->This is a Sec-Fetch-Site bypass too (see <!----></span>https://www.w3.org/TR/fetch-metadata/#redirects<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/fetch-metadata/#redirects"><!---->https://www.w3.org/TR/fetch-metadata/#redirects<!----></a> of the Sec-Fetch-Site spec), but the fix here is probably the same (Populate the populator origin on an redirection to an intent)<span class="line"><!----> of the Sec-Fetch-Site spec), but the fix here is probably the same (Populate the populator origin on an redirection to an intent)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Actually yeah, it does look like the missing redirect chain would be at fault here: <span class="line"><!---->Actually yeah, it does look like the missing redirect chain would be at fault here: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:services/network/sec_header_helpers.cc;drc=8d399817282e3c12ed54eb23ec42a5e418298ec6;l=107<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:services/network/sec_header_helpers.cc;drc=8d399817282e3c12ed54eb23ec42a5e418298ec6;l=107"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:services/network/sec_header_helpers.cc;drc=8d399817282e3c12ed54eb23ec42a5e418298ec6;l=107<!----></a><br><br>We could probably hack in a fix for that, but maybe the problem here is more fundamental?<span class="line"><!---->We could probably hack in a fix for that, but maybe the problem here is more fundamental?<!----></span><br><br>It feels problematic that when we redirect to an app that the app can send the intent back to Chrome with an arbitrary URL on it, and the initiatorOrigin will be whatever origin sent the initial request that got redirected, not whichever origin sent the intent redirect, without any of the other information that would exist on the NavigationHandle, like the redirect chain or the SiteInstance, etc.<span class="line"><!---->It feels problematic that when we redirect to an app that the app can send the intent back to Chrome with an arbitrary URL on it, and the initiatorOrigin will be whatever origin sent the initial request that got redirected, not whichever origin sent the intent redirect, without any of the other information that would exist on the NavigationHandle, like the redirect chain or the SiteInstance, etc.<!----></span><br><br>Thoughts?<span class="line"><!---->Thoughts?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        To make sure I understand this bug, is the situation that<span class="line"><!---->To make sure I understand this bug, is the situation that<!----></span><br><br>A.com -(intent redirect)-> B.com <span class="line"><!---->A.com -(intent redirect)-&gt; B.com <!----></span><br><br>results in B.com being sent its SameSite cookies?<span class="line"><!---->results in B.com being sent its SameSite cookies?<!----></span><br><br>It seems safest to me that if we're navigating from an intent redirect to always assume cross-site. Which in this case would result in SameSite cookies not being sent. Implementation wise this would probably look like using an opaque origin as the initiator.<span class="line"><!---->It seems safest to me that if we're navigating from an intent redirect to always assume cross-site. Which in this case would result in SameSite cookies not being sent. Implementation wise this would probably look like using an opaque origin as the initiator.<!----></span><br><br>In any case, it seems to me that the cookie code is performing correctly* with the information being given to it. It's just the information isn't correct.<span class="line"><!---->In any case, it seems to me that the cookie code is performing correctly* with the information being given to it. It's just the information isn't correct.<!----></span><br><br>* Relatedly, it's known that normal redirections can result in SameSite cookies being sent. This is something we're working on fixing<span class="line"><!---->* Relatedly, it's known that normal redirections can result in SameSite cookies being sent. This is something we're working on fixing<!----></span><br>E.x.:<span class="line"><!---->E.x.:<!----></span><br>A.com --> B.com --> A.com<span class="line"><!---->A.com --&gt; B.com --&gt; A.com<!----></span><br>The final A.com will receive all its SameSite cookies even though we redirected through a different site.<span class="line"><!---->The final A.com will receive all its SameSite cookies even though we redirected through a different site.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        No, the situation is A.com -> B.com (uncommitted) -> (30x intent redirect) -> A.com.<span class="line"><!---->No, the situation is A.com -&gt; B.com (uncommitted) -&gt; (30x intent redirect) -&gt; A.com.<!----></span><br><br>We should be careful not to break the fixes for <span class="line"><!---->We should be careful not to break the fixes for <!----></span>issue 1092451<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1092451" title="Multiple-file download restrictions can be bypassed using Android intents"><!---->issue 1092451<!----></a> and<span class="line"><!----> and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>issue 1092025<span class="line"><!---->issue 1092025<!----></span>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>which is why we initially started tracking the initiatorOrigin through intents.<span class="line"><!---->which is why we initially started tracking the initiatorOrigin through intents.<!----></span><br><br>However, it looks to me like it would be fine to just use an opaque origin as the initiator - I think the important part is we need to be sure not to leave the initiatorOrigin unset, as we treat navigations without an initiator as higher trust and coming from the browser IIRC.<span class="line"><!---->However, it looks to me like it would be fine to just use an opaque origin as the initiator - I think the important part is we need to be sure not to leave the initiatorOrigin unset, as we treat navigations without an initiator as higher trust and coming from the browser IIRC.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        One last question - should we be using an opaque initiator for all intents Chrome receives, or just the ones that come from websites? We generally trust other installed apps slightly more than we trust the web, but maybe it would be best if all intents were treated with less trust.<span class="line"><!---->One last question - should we be using an opaque initiator for all intents Chrome receives, or just the ones that come from websites? We generally trust other installed apps slightly more than we trust the web, but maybe it would be best if all intents were treated with less trust.<!----></span><br><br>(I don't know in practice how much we privilege navigations without an initiatorOrigin, but given past bugs we clearly do to some extent)<span class="line"><!---->(I don't know in practice how much we privilege navigations without an initiatorOrigin, but given past bugs we clearly do to some extent)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by

        If you are asking me, I am unfamiliar with the security model for Android apps so am unsure. But I think treating an open intent from an external app as untrusted may cause some breaking change if an external app decides to launch a user to a site while expecting them to be authenticated via the browser application instead of a webview (due samesite cookie not being sent.) <span class="line"><!---->If you are asking me, I am unfamiliar with the security model for Android apps so am unsure. But I think treating an open intent from an external app as untrusted may cause some breaking change if an external app decides to launch a user to a site while expecting them to be authenticated via the browser application instead of a webview (due samesite cookie not being sent.) <!----></span><br><br>But again, am unsure of security model revolving around external apps.<span class="line"><!---->But again, am unsure of security model revolving around external apps.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Haha sorry, the question was more directed at bingler@, but your response is helpful.<span class="line"><!---->Haha sorry, the question was more directed at bingler@, but your response is helpful.<!----></span><br><br>The problem with Android's app security model is we can't know the sender of intent, so we have no idea whether an association between the target website and the sending app exist.<span class="line"><!---->The problem with Android's app security model is we can't know the sender of intent, so we have no idea whether an association between the target website and the sending app exist.<!----></span><br><br>I must admit after some reading I still have no idea how SameSite cookies are supposed to work in this context, so I'm counting on the navigation folks to guide me here.<span class="line"><!---->I must admit after some reading I still have no idea how SameSite cookies are supposed to work in this context, so I'm counting on the navigation folks to guide me here.<!----></span><br><br>Maybe the solution is when a website sends an intent back to Chrome we should use an opaque origin, but when an app sends an intent to Chrome we should use the origin of the target URL as the initiator so it doesn't look browser initiated but still gets SameSite cookies? Maybe only CCTs where we have a known association with an app should get SameSite cookies from an Intent? Or maybe intents looking browser initiated is totally fine and my concerns are unfounded?<span class="line"><!---->Maybe the solution is when a website sends an intent back to Chrome we should use an opaque origin, but when an app sends an intent to Chrome we should use the origin of the target URL as the initiator so it doesn't look browser initiated but still gets SameSite cookies? Or maybe intents looking browser initiated is totally fine and my concerns are unfounded?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        As far as cookies are concerned, we don't want to send SameSite=Strict cookies unless we're confident that the request came from the same site (or something of equivalent trust). Since coming from an intent isn't necessarily same-site I'm on the side of disallowing them in that case. <span class="line"><!---->As far as cookies are concerned, we don't want to send SameSite=Strict cookies unless we're confident that the request came from the same site (or something of equivalent trust). Since coming from an intent isn't necessarily same-site I'm on the side of disallowing them in that case. <!----></span><br><br>But if we do allow Android apps some extra amount of trust then perhaps it's ok to loosen those restrictions in that case. I don't think I can make that call.<span class="line"><!---->But if we do allow Android apps some extra amount of trust then perhaps it's ok to loosen those restrictions in that case. I don't think I can make that call.<!----></span><br><br>rsesek@, do you have any thoughts?<span class="line"><!---->rsesek@, do you have any thoughts?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      </div><br>
    
        
      
        We should not trust data from incoming Intents, both because (a) other apps on the device may not be trustworthy, and (b) websites can use Intent URLs/redirects to reflect back to Chrome and potentially use it to bypass SameSite restrictions. I don’t know if imposing this restriction will break anything, but I think we should try.<span class="line"><!---->We should not trust data from incoming Intents, both because (a) other apps on the device may not be trustworthy, and (b) websites can use Intent URLs/redirects to reflect back to Chrome and potentially use it to bypass SameSite restrictions. I don’t know if imposing this restriction will break anything, but I think we should try.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        Hi, I can confirm the fix works for both sec-fetch-site and samesite cookie on 109.0.5397.0 Android Chrome Canary.<span class="line"><!---->Hi, I can confirm the fix works for both sec-fetch-site and samesite cookie on 109.0.5397.0 Android Chrome Canary.<!----></span><br><br>For samesite, following steps in <span class="line"><!---->For samesite, following steps in <!----></span>#c9<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c9"><!---->#c9<!----></a> will no longer send the cookie,<span class="line"><!----> will no longer send the cookie,<!----></span><br><br>For sec-fetch-site, using <span class="line"><!---->For sec-fetch-site, using <!----></span>https://morning-vivid-owner.glitch.me/poc-53aevgh<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://morning-vivid-owner.glitch.me/poc-53aevgh"><!---->https://morning-vivid-owner.glitch.me/poc-53aevgh<!----></a> and clicking on the link called test > click on chrome canary on intent-picker, will result in cross-site being sent for sec-fetch-site value.<span class="line"><!----> and clicking on the link called test &gt; click on chrome canary on intent-picker, will result in cross-site being sent for sec-fetch-site value.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users.       VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>Possible to bypass SameSite cookie on Android by redirecting to intent and continuing to stay in Chrome<span class="line"><!---->Possible to bypass SameSite cookie on Android by redirecting to intent and continuing to stay in Chrome<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: [105.0.5195.136] + [stable]<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: [105.0.5195.136] + [stable]<!----></span><br>Operating System: [Android 11; Samsung]<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: [Android 11; Samsung]<!----></span><br><br>Note that I am using a Samsung for this. You must have already have a 2nd browser installed on your Android (in many phones Samsung browser is already installed.) If you are using emulator, you must install Firefox, and change the intent in package parameter in poc.py to point to org.mozilla.firefox.<span class="line"><!---->Note that I am using a Samsung for this. You must have already have a 2nd browser installed on your Android (in many phones Samsung browser is already installed.) If you are using emulator, you must install Firefox, and change the intent in package parameter in poc.py to point to org.mozilla.firefox.<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>1. Start webserver using python3 poc.py<span class="line"><!---->1. Start webserver using python3 poc.py<!----></span><br>2. Visit the webserver, click on (1) to set a samesite=strict cookie<span class="line"><!---->2. Visit the webserver, click on (1) to set a samesite=strict cookie<!----></span><br>3. Click on (2) to verify that the samesite=strict cookie is not set (Cookie header should not show up.)<span class="line"><!---->3. Click on (2) to verify that the samesite=strict cookie is not set (Cookie header should not show up.)<!----></span><br>4. Now, go to the address bar and append /redirect to the current URL, click continue in Chrome. We get redirected cross-site, but we are still sending the samesite=strict cookie.<span class="line"><!---->4. Now, go to the address bar and append /redirect to the current URL, click continue in Chrome. We get redirected cross-site, but we are still sending the samesite=strict cookie.<!----></span><br><br>Expected behaviour: SameSite=Strict cookie should not be sent cross-site (from our redirector site to<span class="line"><!---->Expected behaviour: SameSite=Strict cookie should not be sent cross-site (from our redirector site to<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>httpbin.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="httpbin.org"><!---->httpbin.org<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<b class="line"><!---->Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<!----></b><br>this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<b class="line"><!---->this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Axel Chong<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Axel Chong<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
      
        
          
      
        
          
          poc.html<b><!---->poc.html<!----></b>
          
        <div class="filename">
          
          <b><!---->poc.html<!----></b>
          
        </div>

        I don't have an Android to reproduce, but it seems Android Chrome is treating intents like top-level user-initiated navigations rather than like normal redirects, at least if the intent is redirected to.<span class="line"><!---->I don't have an Android to reproduce, but it seems Android Chrome is treating intents like top-level user-initiated navigations rather than like normal redirects, at least if the intent is redirected to.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      </div><br>

        Actually, I found out that even with normal redirects, SameSite cookie is sent, on default Chrome - <span class="line"><!---->Actually, I found out that even with normal redirects, SameSite cookie is sent, on default Chrome - <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1221316<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1221316"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1221316<!----></a> (this is quite confusing actually, because I remembered it being fixed in this security report - <span class="line"><!----> (this is quite confusing actually, because I remembered it being fixed in this security report - <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> but it seems that it was disabled again). <span class="line"><!----> but it seems that it was disabled again). <!----></span><br><br>However, the secure SameSite behaviour can be enabled on Chrome via a feature flag hidden in chrome://flags > #enable-experimental-cookie-features. When this flag is enabled, then Chrome will not send the cookie on normal redirects, BUT it will still send the cookie for self-intent redirects. I have attached a modified poc.py along with the following STR:<span class="line"><!---->However, the secure SameSite behaviour can be enabled on Chrome via a feature flag hidden in chrome://flags &gt; #enable-experimental-cookie-features. When this flag is enabled, then Chrome will not send the cookie on normal redirects, BUT it will still send the cookie for self-intent redirects. I have attached a modified poc.py along with the following STR:<!----></span><br><br>0. On Android, Go to chrome://flags > Enable experimental cookie features<span class="line"><!---->0. On Android, Go to chrome://flags &gt; Enable experimental cookie features<!----></span><br>1. Start webserver using python3 poc.py<span class="line"><!---->1. Start webserver using python3 poc.py<!----></span><br>2. Visit the webserver, click on (1) to set a samesite=strict cookie<span class="line"><!---->2. Visit the webserver, click on (1) to set a samesite=strict cookie<!----></span><br>3. Click on (2) to verify that the samesite=strict cookie is not set (Cookie header should not show up.)<span class="line"><!---->3. Click on (2) to verify that the samesite=strict cookie is not set (Cookie header should not show up.)<!----></span><br>4. Now, go to the address bar and append /redirect-normal to the current URL, click continue in Chrome. We get redirected cross-site, but we do not send the SameSite cookie due to the feature flag being enabled (no cookie header)<span class="line"><!---->4. Now, go to the address bar and append /redirect-normal to the current URL, click continue in Chrome. We get redirected cross-site, but we do not send the SameSite cookie due to the feature flag being enabled (no cookie header)<!----></span><br>5. Now, go to the address bar and append /redirect-intent to the current URL, click continue in Chrome. We get redirected cross-site, but we are still sending the samesite=strict cookie. (This case is not fixed with the feature flag.)<span class="line"><!---->5. Now, go to the address bar and append /redirect-intent to the current URL, click continue in Chrome. We get redirected cross-site, but we are still sending the samesite=strict cookie. (This case is not fixed with the feature flag.)<!----></span><br><br>Given that <span class="line"><!---->Given that <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1221316<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1221316"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1221316<!----></a> will eventually be re-enabled. This should also be fixed in tandem. There should also be no breaking changes to worry about because only an attacker will use a self-intent to bypass security restrictions for navigations in Chrome.<span class="line"><!----> will eventually be re-enabled. This should also be fixed in tandem. There should also be no breaking changes to worry about because only an attacker will use a self-intent to bypass security restrictions for navigations in Chrome.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Somebody familiar with cookies should triage this.<span class="line"><!---->Somebody familiar with cookies should triage this.<!----></span><br><br>As for the intent picker issues, just to add some context on how this works, when we handle a fallback URL or a self-intent, we do a top-level navigation in a new tab and set the initiatorOrigin to the origin that sent the navigation. I have no idea what the expected behavior is or where we might be going wrong here.<span class="line"><!---->As for the intent picker issues, just to add some context on how this works, when we handle a fallback URL or a self-intent, we do a top-level navigation in a new tab and set the initiatorOrigin to the origin that sent the navigation.         by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1368230#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Oct 4, 2022, 11:29 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1368230#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Oct 4, 2022, 11:29 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        After reading <span class="line"><!---->After reading <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> afaict this is whats happening (from my understanding of SameSite and redirector chains when flag is enabled)<span class="line"><!----> afaict this is whats happening (from my understanding of SameSite and redirector chains when flag is enabled)<!----></span><br><br>1. Secure samesite cookie behaviour + normal redirect (w/ flag enabled)<span class="line"><!---->1. Secure samesite cookie behaviour + normal redirect (w/ flag enabled)<!----></span><br><br>None (entered in omnibox) -> <span class="line"><!---->None (entered in omnibox) -&gt; <!----></span>http://attacker.site<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://attacker.site"><!---->http://attacker.site<!----></a> (redirector origin) -> <span class="line"><!----> (redirector origin) -&gt; <!----></span>http://httpbin.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://httpbin.org"><!---->http://httpbin.org<!----></a> (SameSite cookie not sent w/ flag enabled as origin 2 =/= origin 3)<span class="line"><!----> (SameSite cookie not sent w/ flag enabled as origin 2 =/= origin 3)<!----></span><br><br>2. Secure samesite cookie behaviour + intent redirect (w/ flag enabled)<span class="line"><!---->2. Secure samesite cookie behaviour + intent redirect (w/ flag enabled)<!----></span><br><br>None (entered in omnibox) -> ??? (redirector origin) -> <span class="line"><!---->None (entered in omnibox) -&gt; ??? (redirector origin) -&gt; <!----></span>http://httpbin.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://httpbin.org"><!---->http://httpbin.org<!----></a> (SameSite cookie sent???)<span class="line"><!----> (SameSite cookie sent???)<!----></span><br><br>So the problem lies whether the origin that redirects to intent fills in the ??? and what value it fills in the redirect chain? (correct me if I am wrong)<span class="line"><!---->So the problem lies whether the origin that redirects to intent fills in the ??? and what value it fills in the redirect chain? (correct me if I am wrong)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Hi mthiesse@, I have done some additional test and am fairly confident that the root cause is that the a redirection to an intent is not populating the origin correctly<span class="line"><!---->Hi mthiesse@, I have done some additional test and am fairly confident that the root cause is that the a redirection to an intent is not populating the origin correctly<!----></span><br><br>If you were to go from Site A -> Site B (redirector) -> Site A normally this is what happens:<span class="line"><!---->If you were to go from Site A -&gt; Site B (redirector) -&gt; Site A normally this is what happens:<!----></span><br><br>http://sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sitea.com"><!---->http://sitea.com<!----></a> -> <span class="line"><!----> -&gt; <!----></span>http://siteb.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://siteb.com"><!---->http://siteb.com<!----></a> (normal redirection) --> <span class="line"><!----> (normal redirection) --&gt; <!----></span>http://sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sitea.com"><!---->http://sitea.com<!----></a><br><br>This request has Sec-Fetch-Site of cross-site because the<span class="line"><!---->This request has Sec-Fetch-Site of cross-site because the<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>siteb.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://siteb.com"><!---->siteb.com<!----></a> =/=<span class="line"><!----> =/=<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sitea.com"><!---->sitea.com<!----></a><br><br>However if you were to redirected to an intent, lets say<span class="line"><!---->However if you were to redirected to an intent, lets say<!----></span><br><br>http://sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sitea.com"><!---->http://sitea.com<!----></a> -> <span class="line"><!----> -&gt; <!----></span>http://siteb.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://siteb.com"><!---->http://siteb.com<!----></a> (intent redirection) --> <span class="line"><!----> (intent redirection) --&gt; <!----></span>http://sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sitea.com"><!---->http://sitea.com<!----></a><br><br>Then this request erroneously has Sec-Fetch-Site of same-origin even when<span class="line"><!---->Then this request erroneously has Sec-Fetch-Site of same-origin even when<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>siteb.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://siteb.com"><!---->siteb.com<!----></a> =/=<span class="line"><!----> =/=<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sitea.com"><!---->sitea.com<!----></a>. <span class="line"><!---->. <!----></span><br><br>My guess is that the whenever redirected to an intent it doesn't populate the origin. So origin remains null. Could you verify this @mthiesse?<span class="line"><!---->My guess is that the whenever redirected to an intent it doesn't populate the origin. So origin remains null. Could you verify this @mthiesse?<!----></span><br><br>This is a Sec-Fetch-Site bypass too (see <span class="line"><!---->This is a Sec-Fetch-Site bypass too (see <!----></span>https://www.w3.org/TR/fetch-metadata/#redirects<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/fetch-metadata/#redirects"><!---->https://www.w3.org/TR/fetch-metadata/#redirects<!----></a> of the Sec-Fetch-Site spec), but the fix here is probably the same (Populate the populator origin on an redirection to an intent)<span class="line"><!----> of the Sec-Fetch-Site spec), but the fix here is probably the same (Populate the populator origin on an redirection to an intent)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Actually yeah, it does look like the missing redirect chain would be at fault here: <span class="line"><!---->Actually yeah, it does look like the missing redirect chain would be at fault here: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:services/network/sec_header_helpers.cc;drc=8d399817282e3c12ed54eb23ec42a5e418298ec6;l=107<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:services/network/sec_header_helpers.cc;drc=8d399817282e3c12ed54eb23ec42a5e418298ec6;l=107"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:services/network/sec_header_helpers.cc;drc=8d399817282e3c12ed54eb23ec42a5e418298ec6;l=107<!----></a><br><br>We could probably hack in a fix for that, but maybe the problem here is more fundamental?<span class="line"><!---->We could probably hack in a fix for that, but maybe the problem here is more fundamental?<!----></span><br><br>It feels problematic that when we redirect to an app that the app can send the intent back to Chrome with an arbitrary URL on it, and the initiatorOrigin will be whatever origin sent the initial request that got redirected, not whichever origin sent the intent redirect, without any of the other information that would exist on the NavigationHandle, like the redirect chain or the SiteInstance, etc.<span class="line"><!---->It feels problematic that when we redirect to an app that the app can send the intent back to Chrome with an arbitrary URL on it, and the initiatorOrigin will be whatever origin sent the initial request that got redirected, not whichever origin sent the intent redirect, without any of the other information that would exist on the NavigationHandle, like the redirect chain or the SiteInstance, etc.<!----></span><br><br>Thoughts?<span class="line"><!---->Thoughts?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        To make sure I understand this bug, is the situation that<span class="line"><!---->To make sure I understand this bug, is the situation that<!----></span><br><br>A.com -(intent redirect)-> B.com <span class="line"><!---->A.com -(intent redirect)-&gt; B.com <!----></span><br><br>results in B.com being sent its SameSite cookies?<span class="line"><!---->results in B.com being sent its SameSite cookies?<!----></span><br><br>It seems safest to me that if we're navigating from an intent redirect to always assume cross-site. Which in this case would result in SameSite cookies not being sent. Implementation wise this would probably look like using an opaque origin as the initiator.<span class="line"><!---->It seems safest to me that if we're navigating from an intent redirect to always assume cross-site. Which in this case would result in SameSite cookies not being sent. Implementation wise this would probably look like using an opaque origin as the initiator.<!----></span><br><br>In any case, it seems to me that the cookie code is performing correctly* with the information being given to it. It's just the information isn't correct.<span class="line"><!---->In any case, it seems to me that the cookie code is performing correctly* with the information being given to it. It's just the information isn't correct.<!----></span><br><br>* Relatedly, it's known that normal redirections can result in SameSite cookies being sent. This is something we're working on fixing<span class="line"><!---->* Relatedly, it's known that normal redirections can result in SameSite cookies being sent. This is something we're working on fixing<!----></span><br>E.x.:<span class="line"><!---->E.x.:<!----></span><br>A.com --> B.com --> A.com<span class="line"><!---->A.com --&gt; B.com --&gt; A.com<!----></span><br>The final A.com will receive all its SameSite cookies even though we redirected through a different site.<span class="line"><!---->The final A.com will receive all its SameSite cookies even though we redirected through a different site.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        No, the situation is A.com -> B.com (uncommitted) -> (30x intent redirect) -> A.com.<span class="line"><!---->No, the situation is A.com -&gt; B.com (uncommitted) -&gt; (30x intent redirect) -&gt; A.com.<!----></span><br><br>We should be careful not to break the fixes for <span class="line"><!---->We should be careful not to break the fixes for <!----></span>issue 1092451<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1092451" title="Multiple-file download restrictions can be bypassed using Android intents"><!---->issue 1092451<!----></a> and<span class="line"><!----> and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>issue 1092025<span class="line"><!---->issue 1092025<!----></span>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>which is why we initially started tracking the initiatorOrigin through intents.<span class="line"><!---->which is why we initially started tracking the initiatorOrigin through intents.<!----></span><br><br>However, it looks to me like it would be fine to just use an opaque origin as the initiator - I think the important part is we need to be sure not to leave the initiatorOrigin unset, as we treat navigations without an initiator as higher trust and coming from the browser IIRC.<span class="line"><!---->However, it looks to me like it would be fine to just use an opaque origin as the initiator - I think the important part is we need to be sure not to leave the initiatorOrigin unset, as we treat navigations without an initiator as higher trust and coming from the browser IIRC.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        One last question - should we be using an opaque initiator for all intents Chrome receives, or just the ones that come from websites? We generally trust other installed apps slightly more than we trust the web, but maybe it would be best if all intents were treated with less trust.<span class="line"><!---->One last question - should we be using an opaque initiator for all intents Chrome receives, or just the ones that come from websites? We generally trust other installed apps slightly more than we trust the web, but maybe it would be best if all intents were treated with less trust.<!----></span><br><br>(I don't know in practice how much we privilege navigations without an initiatorOrigin, but given past bugs we clearly do to some extent)<span class="line"><!---->(I don't know in practice how much we privilege navigations without an initiatorOrigin, but given past bugs we clearly do to some extent)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 38<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1368230#c38">Comment 38<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1368230#c38">Comment 38<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Oct 6, 2022, 2:58 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1368230#c38">Comment 38<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Oct 6, 2022, 2:58 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        If you are asking me, I am unfamiliar with the security model for Android apps so am unsure. But I think treating an open intent from an external app as untrusted may cause some breaking change if an external app decides to launch a user to a site while expecting them to be authenticated via the browser application instead of a webview (due samesite cookie not being sent.) <span class="line"><!---->If you are asking me, I am unfamiliar with the security model for Android apps so am unsure. But I think treating an open intent from an external app as untrusted may cause some breaking change if an external app decides to launch a user to a site while expecting them to be authenticated via the browser application instead of a webview (due samesite cookie not being sent.) <!----></span><br><br>But again, am unsure of security model revolving around external apps.<span class="line"><!---->But again, am unsure of security model revolving around external apps.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 39<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1368230#c39">Comment 39<!----></a>

        Haha sorry, the question was more directed at bingler@, but your response is helpful.<span class="line"><!---->Haha sorry, the question was more directed at bingler@, but your response is helpful.<!----></span><br><br>The problem with Android's app security model is we can't know the sender of intent, so we have no idea whether an association between the target website and the sending app exist.<span class="line"><!---->The problem with Android's app security model is we can't know the sender of intent, so we have no idea whether an association between the target website and the sending app exist.<!----></span><br><br>I must admit after some reading I still have no idea how SameSite cookies are supposed to work in this context, so I'm counting on the navigation folks to guide me here.<span class="line"><!---->I must admit after some reading I still have no idea how SameSite cookies are supposed to work in this context, so I'm counting on the navigation folks to guide me here.<!----></span><br><br>Maybe the solution is when a website sends an intent back to Chrome we should use an opaque origin, but when an app sends an intent to Chrome we should use the origin of the target URL as the initiator so it doesn't look browser initiated but still gets SameSite cookies? Maybe only CCTs where we have a known association with an app should get SameSite cookies from an Intent? Or maybe intents looking browser initiated is totally fine and my concerns are unfounded?<span class="line"><!---->Maybe the solution is when a website sends an intent back to Chrome we should use an opaque origin, but when an app sends an intent to Chrome we should use the origin of the target URL as the initiator so it doesn't look browser initiated but still gets SameSite cookies? Maybe only CCTs where we have a known association with an app should get SameSite cookies from an Intent? Or maybe intents looking browser initiated is totally fine and my concerns are unfounded?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        As far as cookies are concerned, we don't want to send SameSite=Strict cookies unless we're confident that the request came from the same site (or something of equivalent trust). Since coming from an intent isn't necessarily same-site I'm on the side of disallowing them in that case. <span class="line"><!---->As far as cookies are concerned, we don't want to send SameSite=Strict cookies unless we're confident that the request came from the same site (or something of equivalent trust). Since coming from an intent isn't necessarily same-site I'm on the side of disallowing them in that case. <!----></span><br><br>But if we do allow Android apps some extra amount of trust then perhaps it's ok to loosen those restrictions in that case. I don't think I can make that call.<span class="line"><!---->But if we do allow Android apps some extra amount of trust then perhaps it's ok to loosen those restrictions in that case. I don't think I can make that call.<!----></span><br><br>rsesek@, do you have any thoughts?<span class="line"><!---->rsesek@, do you have any thoughts?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Owner:<strong><!---->Owner:</strong>
          
          bingler@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Owner:</strong>
          
          bingler@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        We should not trust data from incoming Intents, both because (a) other apps on the device may not be trustworthy, and (b) websites can use Intent URLs/redirects to reflect back to Chrome and potentially use it to bypass SameSite restrictions. I don’t know if imposing this restriction will break anything, but I think we should try.<span class="line"><!---->We should not trust data from incoming Intents, both because (a) other apps on the device may not be trustworthy, and (b) websites can use Intent URLs/redirects to reflect back to Chrome and potentially use it to bypass SameSite restrictions. I don’t know if imposing this restriction will break anything, but I think we should try.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">

        Hi, I can confirm the fix works for both sec-fetch-site and samesite cookie on 109.0.5397.0 Android Chrome Canary.<span class="line"><!---->Hi, I can confirm the fix works for both sec-fetch-site and samesite cookie on 109.0.5397.0 Android Chrome Canary.<!----></span><br><br>For samesite, following steps in <span class="line"><!---->For samesite, following steps in <!----></span>#c9<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c9"><!---->#c9<!----></a> will no longer send the cookie,<span class="line"><!----> will no longer send the cookie,<!----></span><br><br>For sec-fetch-site, using <span class="line"><!---->For sec-fetch-site, using <!----></span>https://morning-vivid-owner.glitch.me/poc-53aevgh<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://morning-vivid-owner.glitch.me/poc-53aevgh"><!---->https://morning-vivid-owner.glitch.me/poc-53aevgh<!----></a> and clicking on the link called test > click on chrome canary on intent-picker, will result in cross-site being sent for sec-fetch-site value.<span class="line"><!----> and clicking on the link called test &gt; click on chrome canary on intent-picker, will result in cross-site being sent for sec-fetch-site value.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users.       VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>Possible to bypass SameSite cookie on Android by redirecting to intent and continuing to stay in Chrome<span class="line"><!---->Possible to bypass SameSite cookie on Android by redirecting to intent and continuing to stay in Chrome<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: [105.0.5195.136] + [stable]<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: [105.0.5195.136] + [stable]<!----></span><br>Operating System: [Android 11; Samsung]<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: [Android 11; Samsung]<!----></span><br><br>Note that I am using a Samsung for this. You must have already have a 2nd browser installed on your Android (in many phones Samsung browser is already installed.) If you are using emulator, you must install Firefox, and change the intent in package parameter in poc.py to point to org.mozilla.firefox.<span class="line"><!---->Note that I am using a Samsung for this. You must have already have a 2nd browser installed on your Android (in many phones Samsung browser is already installed.) If you are using emulator, you must install Firefox, and change the intent in package parameter in poc.py to point to org.mozilla.firefox.<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>1. Start webserver using python3 poc.py<span class="line"><!---->1. Start webserver using python3 poc.py<!----></span><br>2. Visit the webserver, click on (1) to set a samesite=strict cookie<span class="line"><!---->2. Visit the webserver, click on (1) to set a samesite=strict cookie<!----></span><br>3. Click on (2) to verify that the samesite=strict cookie is not set (Cookie header should not show up.)<span class="line"><!---->3. Click on (2) to verify that the samesite=strict cookie is not set (Cookie header should not show up.)<!----></span><br>4. Now, go to the address bar and append /redirect to the current URL, click continue in Chrome. We get redirected cross-site, but we are still sending the samesite=strict cookie.<span class="line"><!---->4. Now, go to the address bar and append /redirect to the current URL, click continue in Chrome. We get redirected cross-site, but we are still sending the samesite=strict cookie.<!----></span><br><br>Expected behaviour: SameSite=Strict cookie should not be sent cross-site (from our redirector site to<span class="line"><!---->Expected behaviour: SameSite=Strict cookie should not be sent cross-site (from our redirector site to<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>httpbin.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="httpbin.org"><!---->httpbin.org<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<b class="line"><!---->Externally reported security bugs may appear in Chrome release notes. If<!----></b><br>this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<b class="line"><!---->this bug is included, how would you like to be credited?<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Axel Chong<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Axel Chong<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        video: no intent selection is required<span class="line"><!---->video: no intent selection is required<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I don't have an Android to reproduce, but it seems Android Chrome is treating intents like top-level user-initiated navigations rather than like normal redirects, at least if the intent is redirected to.<span class="line"><!---->I don't have an Android to reproduce, but it seems Android Chrome is treating intents like top-level user-initiated navigations rather than like normal redirects, at least if the intent is redirected to.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

      haxat...@gmail.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->haxat...@gmail.com<!----></span>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1368230#c9">Comment 9<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Sep 30, 2022, 5:25 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1368230#c9">Comment 9<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Sep 30, 2022, 5:25 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Actually, I found out that even with normal redirects, SameSite cookie is sent, on default Chrome - <span class="line"><!---->Actually, I found out that even with normal redirects, SameSite cookie is sent, on default Chrome - <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1221316<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1221316"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1221316<!----></a> (this is quite confusing actually, because I remembered it being fixed in this security report - <span class="line"><!----> (this is quite confusing actually, because I remembered it being fixed in this security report - <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> but it seems that it was disabled again). <span class="line"><!----> but it seems that it was disabled again). <!----></span><br><br>However, the secure SameSite behaviour can be enabled on Chrome via a feature flag hidden in chrome://flags > #enable-experimental-cookie-features. When this flag is enabled, then Chrome will not send the cookie on normal redirects, BUT it will still send the cookie for self-intent redirects. I have attached a modified poc.py along with the following STR:<span class="line"><!---->However, the secure SameSite behaviour can be enabled on Chrome via a feature flag hidden in chrome://flags &gt; #enable-experimental-cookie-features. When this flag is enabled, then Chrome will not send the cookie on normal redirects, BUT it will still send the cookie for self-intent redirects. I have attached a modified poc.py along with the following STR:<!----></span><br><br>0. On Android, Go to chrome://flags > Enable experimental cookie features<span class="line"><!---->0. On Android, Go to chrome://flags &gt; Enable experimental cookie features<!----></span><br>1. Start webserver using python3 poc.py<span class="line"><!---->1. Start webserver using python3 poc.py<!----></span><br>2. Visit the webserver, click on (1) to set a samesite=strict cookie<span class="line"><!---->2. Visit the webserver, click on (1) to set a samesite=strict cookie<!----></span><br>3. Click on (2) to verify that the samesite=strict cookie is not set (Cookie header should not show up.)<span class="line"><!---->3. Click on (2) to verify that the samesite=strict cookie is not set (Cookie header should not show up.)<!----></span><br>4. Now, go to the address bar and append /redirect-normal to the current URL, click continue in Chrome. We get redirected cross-site, but we do not send the SameSite cookie due to the feature flag being enabled (no cookie header)<span class="line"><!---->4. Now, go to the address bar and append /redirect-normal to the current URL, click continue in Chrome. We get redirected cross-site, but we do not send the SameSite cookie due to the feature flag being enabled (no cookie header)<!----></span><br>5. Now, go to the address bar and append /redirect-intent to the current URL, click continue in Chrome. We get redirected cross-site, but we are still sending the samesite=strict cookie. (This case is not fixed with the feature flag.)<span class="line"><!---->5. Now, go to the address bar and append /redirect-intent to the current URL, click continue in Chrome. We get redirected cross-site, but we are still sending the samesite=strict cookie. (This case is not fixed with the feature flag.)<!----></span><br><br>Given that <span class="line"><!---->Given that <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1221316<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1221316"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1221316<!----></a> will eventually be re-enabled. This should also be fixed in tandem. There should also be no breaking changes to worry about because only an attacker will use a self-intent to bypass security restrictions for navigations in Chrome.<span class="line"><!----> will eventually be re-enabled. This should also be fixed in tandem. There should also be no breaking changes to worry about because only an attacker will use a self-intent to bypass security restrictions for navigations in Chrome.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
            
      
        
          
          poc.py<b><!---->poc.py<!----></b>
          
        <div class="filename">
          
          <b><!---->poc.py<!----></b>
          
        </div>
        
          
            705 bytes<div class="filesize"><!---->705 bytes<!----></div>

        Somebody familiar with cookies should triage this.<span class="line"><!---->Somebody familiar with cookies should triage this.<!----></span><br><br>As for the intent picker issues, just to add some context on how this works, when we handle a fallback URL or a self-intent, we do a top-level navigation in a new tab and set the initiatorOrigin to the origin that sent the navigation. I have no idea what the expected behavior is or where we might be going wrong here.<span class="line"><!---->As for the intent picker issues, just to add some context on how this works, when we handle a fallback URL or a self-intent, we do a top-level navigation in a new tab and set the initiatorOrigin to the origin that sent the navigation.         After reading <span class="line"><!---->After reading <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=830101<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> afaict this is whats happening (from my understanding of SameSite and redirector chains when flag is enabled)<span class="line"><!----> afaict this is whats happening (from my understanding of SameSite and redirector chains when flag is enabled)<!----></span><br><br>1. Secure samesite cookie behaviour + normal redirect (w/ flag enabled)<span class="line"><!---->1. Secure samesite cookie behaviour + normal redirect (w/ flag enabled)<!----></span><br><br>None (entered in omnibox) -> <span class="line"><!---->None (entered in omnibox) -&gt; <!----></span>http://attacker.site<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://attacker.site"><!---->http://attacker.site<!----></a> (redirector origin) -> <span class="line"><!----> (redirector origin) -&gt; <!----></span>http://httpbin.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://httpbin.org"><!---->http://httpbin.org<!----></a> (SameSite cookie not sent w/ flag enabled as origin 2 =/= origin 3)<span class="line"><!----> (SameSite cookie not sent w/ flag enabled as origin 2 =/= origin 3)<!----></span><br><br>2. Secure samesite cookie behaviour + intent redirect (w/ flag enabled)<span class="line"><!---->2. Secure samesite cookie behaviour + intent redirect (w/ flag enabled)<!----></span><br><br>None (entered in omnibox) -> ??? (redirector origin) -> <span class="line"><!---->None (entered in omnibox) -&gt; ??? (redirector origin) -&gt; <!----></span>http://httpbin.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://httpbin.org"><!---->http://httpbin.org<!----></a> (SameSite cookie sent???)<span class="line"><!----> (SameSite cookie sent???)<!----></span><br><br>So the problem lies whether the origin that redirects to intent fills in the ??? and what value it fills in the redirect chain? (correct me if I am wrong)<span class="line"><!---->So the problem lies whether the origin that redirects to intent fills in the ??? and what value it fills in the redirect chain? (correct me if I am wrong)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Hi mthiesse@, I have done some additional test and am fairly confident that the root cause is that the a redirection to an intent is not populating the origin correctly<span class="line"><!---->Hi mthiesse@, I have done some additional test and am fairly confident that the root cause is that the a redirection to an intent is not populating the origin correctly<!----></span><br><br>If you were to go from Site A -> Site B (redirector) -> Site A normally this is what happens:<span class="line"><!---->If you were to go from Site A -&gt; Site B (redirector) -&gt; Site A normally this is what happens:<!----></span><br><br>http://sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sitea.com"><!---->http://sitea.com<!----></a> -> <span class="line"><!----> -&gt; <!----></span>http://siteb.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://siteb.com"><!---->http://siteb.com<!----></a> (normal redirection) --> <span class="line"><!----> (normal redirection) --&gt; <!----></span>http://sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sitea.com"><!---->http://sitea.com<!----></a><br><br>This request has Sec-Fetch-Site of cross-site because the<span class="line"><!---->This request has Sec-Fetch-Site of cross-site because the<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>siteb.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://siteb.com"><!---->siteb.com<!----></a> =/=<span class="line"><!----> =/=<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sitea.com"><!---->sitea.com<!----></a><br><br>However if you were to redirected to an intent, lets say<span class="line"><!---->However if you were to redirected to an intent, lets say<!----></span><br><br>http://sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sitea.com"><!---->http://sitea.com<!----></a> -> <span class="line"><!----> -&gt; <!----></span>http://siteb.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://siteb.com"><!---->http://siteb.com<!----></a> (intent redirection) --> <span class="line"><!----> (intent redirection) --&gt; <!----></span>http://sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://sitea.com"><!---->http://sitea.com<!----></a><br><br>Then this request erroneously has Sec-Fetch-Site of same-origin even when<span class="line"><!---->Then this request erroneously has Sec-Fetch-Site of same-origin even when<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>siteb.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://siteb.com"><!---->siteb.com<!----></a> =/=<span class="line"><!----> =/=<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>sitea.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sitea.com"><!---->sitea.com<!----></a>. <span class="line"><!---->. <!----></span><br><br>My guess is that the whenever redirected to an intent it doesn't populate the origin. So origin remains null. Could you verify this @mthiesse?<span class="line"><!---->My guess is that the whenever redirected to an intent it doesn't populate the origin. So origin remains null. Could you verify this @mthiesse?<!----></span><br><br>This is a Sec-Fetch-Site bypass too (see <span class="line"><!---->This is a Sec-Fetch-Site bypass too (see <!----></span>https://www.w3.org/TR/fetch-metadata/#redirects<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/fetch-metadata/#redirects"><!---->https://www.w3.org/TR/fetch-metadata/#redirects<!----></a> of the Sec-Fetch-Site spec), but the fix here is probably the same (Populate the populator origin on an redirection to an intent)<span class="line"><!----> of the Sec-Fetch-Site spec), but the fix here is probably the same (Populate the populator origin on an redirection to an intent)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Actually yeah, it does look like the missing redirect chain would be at fault here: <span class="line"><!---->Actually yeah, it does look like the missing redirect chain would be at fault here: <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:services/network/sec_header_helpers.cc;drc=8d399817282e3c12ed54eb23ec42a5e418298ec6;l=107<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:services/network/sec_header_helpers.cc;drc=8d399817282e3c12ed54eb23ec42a5e418298ec6;l=107"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:services/network/sec_header_helpers.cc;drc=8d399817282e3c12ed54eb23ec42a5e418298ec6;l=107<!----></a><br><br>We could probably hack in a fix for that, but maybe the problem here is more fundamental?<span class="line"><!---->We could probably hack in a fix for that, but maybe the problem here is more fundamental?<!----></span><br><br>It feels problematic that when we redirect to an app that the app can send the intent back to Chrome with an arbitrary URL on it, and the initiatorOrigin will be whatever origin sent the initial request that got redirected, not whichever origin sent the intent redirect, without any of the other information that would exist on the NavigationHandle, like the redirect chain or the SiteInstance, etc.<span class="line"><!---->It feels problematic that when we redirect to an app that the app can send the intent back to Chrome with an arbitrary URL on it, and the initiatorOrigin will be whatever origin sent the initial request that got redirected, not whichever origin sent the intent redirect, without any of the other information that would exist on the NavigationHandle, like the redirect chain or the SiteInstance, etc.<!----></span><br><br>Thoughts?<span class="line"><!---->Thoughts?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        To make sure I understand this bug, is the situation that<span class="line"><!---->To make sure I understand this bug, is the situation that<!----></span><br><br>A.com -(intent redirect)-> B.com <span class="line"><!---->A.com -(intent redirect)-&gt; B.com <!----></span><br><br>results in B.com being sent its SameSite cookies?<span class="line"><!---->results in B.com being sent its SameSite cookies?<!----></span><br><br>It seems safest to me that if we're navigating from an intent redirect to always assume cross-site. Which in this case would result in SameSite cookies not being sent. Implementation wise this would probably look like using an opaque origin as the initiator.<span class="line"><!---->It seems safest to me that if we're navigating from an intent redirect to always assume cross-site. Which in this case would result in SameSite cookies not being sent. Implementation wise this would probably look like using an opaque origin as the initiator.<!----></span><br><br>In any case, it seems to me that the cookie code is performing correctly* with the information being given to it. It's just the information isn't correct.<span class="line"><!---->In any case, it seems to me that the cookie code is performing correctly* with the information being given to it. It's just the information isn't correct.<!----></span><br><br>* Relatedly, it's known that normal redirections can result in SameSite cookies being sent. This is something we're working on fixing<span class="line"><!---->* Relatedly, it's known that normal redirections can result in SameSite cookies being sent. This is something we're working on fixing<!----></span><br>E.x.:<span class="line"><!---->E.x.:<!----></span><br>A.com --> B.com --> A.com<span class="line"><!---->A.com --&gt; B.com --&gt; A.com<!----></span><br>The final A.com will receive all its SameSite cookies even though we redirected through a different site.<span class="line"><!---->The final A.com will receive all its SameSite cookies even though we redirected through a different site.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        No, the situation is A.com -> B.com (uncommitted) -> (30x intent redirect) -> A.com.<span class="line"><!---->No, the situation is A.com -&gt; B.com (uncommitted) -&gt; (30x intent redirect) -&gt; A.com.<!----></span><br><br>We should be careful not to break the fixes for <span class="line"><!---->We should be careful not to break the fixes for <!----></span>issue 1092451<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1092451" title="Multiple-file download restrictions can be bypassed using Android intents"><!---->issue 1092451<!----></a> and<span class="line"><!----> and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>issue 1092025<span class="line"><!---->issue 1092025<!----></span>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>which is why we initially started tracking the initiatorOrigin through intents.<span class="line"><!---->which is why we initially started tracking the initiatorOrigin through intents.<!----></span><br><br>However, it looks to me like it would be fine to just use an opaque origin as the initiator - I think the important part is we need to be sure not to leave the initiatorOrigin unset, as we treat navigations without an initiator as higher trust and coming from the browser IIRC.<span class="line"><!---->However, it looks to me like it would be fine to just use an opaque origin as the initiator - I think the important part is we need to be sure not to leave the initiatorOrigin unset, as we treat navigations without an initiator as higher trust and coming from the browser IIRC.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        One last question - should we be using an opaque initiator for all intents Chrome receives, or just the ones that come from websites? We generally trust other installed apps slightly more than we trust the web, but maybe it would be best if all intents were treated with less trust.<span class="line"><!---->One last question - should we be using an opaque initiator for all intents Chrome receives, or just the ones that come from websites? We generally trust other installed apps slightly more than we trust the web, but maybe it would be best if all intents were treated with less trust.<!----></span><br><br>(I don't know in practice how much we privilege navigations without an initiatorOrigin, but given past bugs we clearly do to some extent)<span class="line"><!---->(I don't know in practice how much we privilege navigations without an initiatorOrigin, but given past bugs we clearly do to some extent)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        If you are asking me, I am unfamiliar with the security model for Android apps so am unsure. But I think treating an open intent from an external app as untrusted may cause some breaking change if an external app decides to launch a user to a site while expecting them to be authenticated via the browser application instead of a webview (due samesite cookie not being sent.) <span class="line"><!---->If you are asking me, I am unfamiliar with the security model for Android apps so am unsure. But I think treating an open intent from an external app as untrusted may cause some breaking change if an external app decides to launch a user to a site while expecting them to be authenticated via the browser application instead of a webview (due samesite cookie not being sent.) <!----></span><br><br>But again, am unsure of security model revolving around external apps.<span class="line"><!---->But again, am unsure of security model revolving around external apps.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Haha sorry, the question was more directed at bingler@, but your response is helpful.<span class="line"><!---->Haha sorry, the question was more directed at bingler@, but your response is helpful.<!----></span><br><br>The problem with Android's app security model is we can't know the sender of intent, so we have no idea whether an association between the target website and the sending app exist.<span class="line"><!---->The problem with Android's app security model is we can't know the sender of intent, so we have no idea whether an association between the target website and the sending app exist.<!----></span><br><br>I must admit after some reading I still have no idea how SameSite cookies are supposed to work in this context, so I'm counting on the navigation folks to guide me here.<span class="line"><!---->I must admit after some reading I still have no idea how SameSite cookies are supposed to work in this context, so I'm counting on the navigation folks to guide me here.<!----></span><br><br>Maybe the solution is when a website sends an intent back to Chrome we should use an opaque origin, but when an app sends an intent to Chrome we should use the origin of the target URL as the initiator so it doesn't look browser initiated but still gets SameSite cookies? Maybe only CCTs where we have a known association with an app should get SameSite cookies from an Intent? Or maybe intents looking browser initiated is totally fine and my concerns are unfounded?<span class="line"><!---->Maybe the solution is when a website sends an intent back to Chrome we should use an opaque origin, but when an app sends an intent to Chrome we should use the origin of the target URL as the initiator so it doesn't look browser initiated but still gets SameSite cookies?
